questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. He had no fractures and no hydrocephalus or raised intracranial pressure. Non-contrast CT was performed and was found to be normal. The likely diagnosis is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A Diffuse axonal injury

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of the patient who had an RTA presents with an abnormal clinical manifestation and no imaging abnormality suggests diffuse axonal injury.

 

C/F: High energy trauma (road traffic accident) + Low GCS score / comatose

Initial investigation for DAI→ NCCT: Normal or tiny microbleeds

IOC for DAI → MRI

Sequence of MRI best: SWI/ Gradient MR: Shows blooming suggestive of axonal shearing

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Post-concussion syndrome: Patients with post-concussion syndrome have mild traumatic brain injury. It does not present with a severe clinical status as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Extra Dural hemorrhage: Extradural hemorrhage results secondary to trauma to head. The bleeding is usually arterial and blood collects between outer dura and inner table of the skull. It can very well be visualized on CT.

 

Option D. Post-concussion syndrome: A cerebral herniation is a shift of cerebral tissue in an adjacent space. Intracranial brain herniation can be classified into 3 types - subfalcine, trans tentorial and tonsillar. A distinct clinical picture can be produced as a result of compression of neurovascular structures by the herniating part. CT is the imaging modality of choice because it can be done rapidly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of road traffic accidents where a patient presents with a significant neurological deficit and a normal initial CT scan, diffuse axonal injury should be considered. An MRI with specific sequences is required to confirm the diagnosis and understand the extent of injury.

questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia, arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were present over the body. Probable drug of abuse in above patient is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a powerful sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia (rapid heart rate) and arrhythmias (irregular heartbeats). One of the distinctive signs of cocaine abuse is the presence of multiple scratch marks on the body. This occurs due to tactile hallucinations, commonly referred to as "cocaine bugs" or "formication/ Magnan Symptoms" where the user feels as though insects are crawling on or under their skin, causing them to scratch incessantly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is a central nervous system depressant, not a stimulant. It typically causes bradycardia (slow heart rate) rather than tachycardia or arrhythmias. It also does not produce tactile hallucinations or scratch marks.

 

Option C. Datura: Although Datura can cause tachycardia and arrhythmias due to its anticholinergic properties, it is not commonly known as a drug of abuse. Moreover, Datura does not typically cause the tactile hallucinations that result in scratch marks.

 

Option D. Cannabis: Cannabis has minimal physiological effects compared to cocaine. It is unlikely to cause significant tachycardia or arrhythmias. Cannabis also does not cause tactile hallucinations or the resultant scratch marks seen with cocaine use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine abuse can be identified by symptoms of tachycardia, arrhythmias, and the presence of scratch marks due to tactile hallucinations (cocaine bugs).

 

“Cocaine is the drug of abuse”

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal tumors that commonly present with gastrointestinal bleeding. They are characterized by mutations that lead to the overactivity of tyrosine kinase. The most common mutation associated with GISTs is in the CKIT gene, which leads to the activation of the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase.

 

NRG-1 (Neuregulin 1):

 

NRG-1 is a gene that is part of the epidermal growth factor receptor family. It is not associated with GISTs. Instead, NRG-1 is implicated in the pathogenesis of mental health disorders, such as schizophrenia. Therefore, it is not used as a marker for GISTs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. KIT: KIT mutations are the most common genetic alterations found in GISTs and are critical for the diagnosis and treatment of these tumors.

 

Option B. PDGFR: Mutations in the PDGFR gene occur in a subset of GISTs and play a role similar to KIT mutations in tumor development.

 

Option C. SDH: SDH mutations are linked to Carney-Stratakis syndrome and are significant markers in a subset of GISTs. These mutations lead to defects in cellular respiration and are associated with the development of GISTs and paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who is a chronic alcoholic was presented with complaints of confusion, tingling sensation. His history revealed polished rice is his main diet. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beriberi

 

The patient described in the question is a chronic alcoholic and has a diet primarily consisting of polished rice. Both factors are significant because they contribute to a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Alcohol inhibits the absorption of thiamine in the intestines, and polished rice, which has had its aleurone layer removed during processing, is devoid of thiamine.

 

Thiamine deficiency can lead to Beriberi, which has two forms:

 

  • Dry Beriberi: Characterized by symmetrical motor and sensory neuropathy, often with symptoms such as confusion, tingling, tenderness, and muscle cramps. The symptoms mentioned in the question, such as confusion and tingling, align with this form.
  • Wet Beriberi: This form is associated with high-output cardiac failure and edema, which is not highlighted in this patient's symptoms but is also a consequence of severe thiamine deficiency.

 

Given the patient’s symptoms and history, the correct diagnosis is Beriberi due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phrynoderma: This is a condition associated with vitamin A deficiency, leading to follicular hyperkeratosis. It is not related to the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, resulting in scaling on the skin’s surface. It is unrelated to the neurological symptoms and dietary history presented in the question.

 

Option D. Eczema: Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, is a condition that makes the skin red, inflamed, and itchy. It does not correlate with the patient’s symptoms of confusion and tingling, nor with thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcoholism and a diet primarily consisting of polished rice can lead to thiamine deficiency, resulting in Beriberi, which can manifest as either dry (neurological symptoms) or wet (cardiac symptoms) Beriberi.

questions.text: A female 29 years old is on a Combined OCP regimen for contraception. All of the following cancers may be seen in her except (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ovarian cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs) have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer. OCPs are protective against benign breast diseases, benign & malignant ovarian diseases but have been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and cervical cancer. Thus, ovarian cancer is the correct answer, as it is the exception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast cancer: Combined OCPs may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: There is evidence that long-term use of combined OCPs can increase the risk of cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined Oral Contraceptive Pills reduce the risk of ovarian cancer while potentially increasing the risk of breast and cervical cancers.

questions.text: A child presented to PHC OPD with skin rash and depigmented hair. He gives a history of swollen/bleeding gums. X-ray picture is shown below. He is suffering from: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Copper deficiency


The clinical presentation of the child, including skin rash, depigmented hair, swollen/bleeding gums, and the X-ray findings, suggests a deficiency that closely mimics scurvy (vitamin C deficiency). However, in this question, the exact cause is copper deficiency, which shares similar symptoms and radiological appearances with scurvy. Copper plays a crucial role in various metabolic pathways, including those influenced by vitamin C, such as collagen synthesis and connective tissue health. Copper deficiency is known as pseudoscurvy because it presents with nearly identical clinical and radiological features as vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zinc deficiency: Zinc deficiency typically presents with symptoms such as delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, and dermatitis, particularly around orifices. It does not cause the specific combination of bleeding gums, depigmented hair, and the radiological changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency usually presents with symptoms related to anemia, such as fatigue, pallor, and pica. While it can cause brittle nails and hair changes, it does not present with bleeding gums and specific X-ray findings as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency: Selenium deficiency primarily affects the heart and muscles, leading to conditions like Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy) and muscle weakness. It does not cause the bleeding gums, depigmented hair, or the bone abnormalities observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Copper deficiency can mimic vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) in its clinical and radiological presentation, a condition often referred to as pseudoscurvy.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is on losartan develops an HbA1c level of 8.1%. Which of the following drugs would you replace losartan with? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telmisartan

 

Telmisartan is the appropriate choice for a hypertensive patient with an elevated HbA1c level (8.1%), indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Telmisartan, an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), has unique properties among ARBs due to its partial agonistic activity on peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPAR-gamma). PPAR-gamma agonists can improve insulin sensitivity and have beneficial effects on glycemic control. This makes Telmisartan particularly useful for patients managing both hypertension and diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not have the beneficial effects on glycemic control seen with Telmisartan and would not be the preferred choice in a patient with elevated HbA1c.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker. While effective for hypertension, beta-blockers can potentially worsen glycemic control and are not ideal for patients with diabetes.

 

Option D. Olmesartan: Olmesartan is another ARB, but unlike Telmisartan, it lacks PPAR-gamma agonistic activity. Thus, it does not offer the additional benefit of improving insulin sensitivity and glycemic control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For hypertensive patients with diabetes and elevated HbA1c levels, Telmisartan is the preferred replacement for losartan due to its PPAR-gamma agonistic activity, which helps improve glycemic control.

questions.text: A public health officer is reviewing populations targeted by the HIV sentinel surveillance program. Which group is NOT traditionally included in HIV sentinel surveillance? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) STD clinic attendees

 

  • Routine monitoring for HIV is generally not conducted among individuals visiting STD clinics.
  • Sentinel surveillance serves to enhance the existing notification systems employed for disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single male migrants: Included in sentinel surveillance as they are considered at high risk.

 

Option B. Truck drivers: Included due to their high-risk behavior.

 

Option D. Antenatal women: Included to monitor HIV prevalence among pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sites for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

 

  • A pregnant woman of reproductive age and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.
  • Female sex workers.
  • Hijra/Transgenders.
  • IV drug users
  • Truckers.
  • Homosexual Men
  • Migrants.

questions.text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dog

 

The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canis which are its definitive hosts.

 

The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man.

 

Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

 

Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.

 

Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cat: Incorrect, as cats are not typical definitive hosts for Echinococcus species.

 

Option C. Swine: Incorrect, swine serve as one of the intermediate hosts, not as definitive hosts where the adult tapeworms reside.

 

Option D. Sheep: Incorrect, similar to swine, sheep act as intermediate hosts where larval stages develop, not as definitive hosts for the adult form of the tapeworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dogs are the definitive hosts for the adult form of Echinococcus, underscoring the importance of proper hygiene and preventive measures in areas where these animals are common to minimize the risk of transmission and subsequent human infection.

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria

 

The picture depicts artemisin-based combination therapy (ACT). This medicine is used to treat falciparum malaria.

 

ARTEMISINS - Artesunate and Artemether

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following listed minerals is NOT typically classified as a trace nutrient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Calcium

 

  • Carbohydrates, fats and proteins are Macronutrients (Proximate principles).  
  • Micronutrients include Calcium, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Sodium, Potassium, Iron, Zinc and Vitamins.
  • Trace nutrients include iron, manganese, copper, iodine, zinc, cobalt, fluoride and selenium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium is a macronutrient, needed in larger amounts. Selenium, iodine, and copper are trace nutrients, required in smaller quantities.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

 

  • The reporting standards employed for presenting the outcomes of Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are known as CONSORT, which stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) is intended for reporting the outcomes of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), not diagnostic studies.
  • The correct reporting guidelines for diagnostic studies are STARD (Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observational study – MOOSE: MOOSE is Meta-analyses Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology

 

Option B. Systematic review – PRISMA: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement (2009) helps systematic reviewers transparently report why the review was done, what the authors did, and what they found.

 

Option D. Case report – CARE: The CARE guidelines (for CAse REports) were developed by an international group of experts to support an increase in the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - More reporting guidelines can be found on Equator network

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not carry parasympathetic fibers? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trochlear

 

Explanation:

 

Among the cranial nerves, only the oculomotor (CN III), facial (CN VII), glossopharyngeal (CN IX), and vagus (CN X) nerves carry parasympathetic fibers. These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity in the head, neck, and face area. The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is not involved in parasympathetic innervation.

 

The parasympathetic ganglia associated with these cranial nerves are:

 

  • Oculomotor (CN III): Ciliary ganglion, related to the eye
  • Facial (CN VII): Pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia, causing secretion from nasal, palatine, and submandibular glands
  • Glossopharyngeal (CN IX): Otic ganglion
  • Vagus (CN X): Responsible for secretion from the gastrointestinal tract (GIT)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial: The facial nerve (CN VII) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the pterygopalatine and submandibular ganglia.

 

Option C. Oculomotor: The oculomotor nerve (CN III) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the ciliary ganglion.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries parasympathetic fibers and is associated with the otic ganglion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cranial nerves that carry parasympathetic fibers are CN III, CN VII, CN IX, and CN X (3, 7, 9, 10). These nerves are responsible for parasympathetic activity and secretion in the head, neck, and face area, as well as the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Plasmodium falciparum is identified in the peripheral smear by the presence of multiple rings within a single red blood cell (RBC) and the characteristic headphone-like structure known as the accolé form or appliqué form. In the provided image, multiple rings are visible in some RBCs, and a distinctive headphone-like structure can be observed, which are hallmarks of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium vivax: This species typically shows a single ring per RBC and can form larger, amoeboid shapes in the late trophozoite stage, which are not seen in this image.

 

Option C. Plasmodium ovale: This species also shows a single ring per RBC and is often characterized by an oval shape of the infected RBC and ragged cell edges, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Plasmodium malariae: This species shows a band form of the trophozoite across the RBC, which is not present in the image. It also typically has fewer merozoites in the schizont stage compared to Plasmodium falciparum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Cysto-Urethroscope

 

The image depicts a double J (DJ) stent placed in the ureter, commonly used to keep the ureter patent, especially after procedures like Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) or Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL). The correct method for inserting or removing this stent is through cystoscopy or cysto-urethroscopy, which involves visualizing the ureteric orifices and directly inserting the stent into the desired ureter.

 

Cysto-urethroscopy allows the surgeon to view the bladder and the openings of the ureters, facilitating the accurate placement of the stent without needing to enter the ureter directly. This approach is similar to the technique used in Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for biliary stenting, where a stent is placed via the ampulla using an endoscope, rather than inserting a scope into the duct itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephroscope: A nephroscope is used for direct visualization of the kidney's interior, typically for removing stones or other intrarenal procedures, not for inserting ureteral stents.

 

Option C. Ureteroscope: While ureteroscopes are used for procedures directly within the ureter, such as stone removal, the insertion of DJ stents is typically done via cystoscopy, not ureteroscopy.

 

Option D. USG guided: Ultrasound guidance is not commonly used for placing ureteral stents as it does not provide the visual access needed to navigate the ureteric orifices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The insertion of a double J stent in the ureter is performed using a cysto-urethroscope, which allows for direct visualization of the bladder and ureteric orifices, enabling accurate stent placement.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. General somatic

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

 

The question is regarding afferent columns hence we will only look at the afferent columns to arrange these options and not the whole arrangement of all the columns in the diagram.

 

The afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be categorized from medial to lateral into four types: general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, and special somatic.

 

 

 

The subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle can be organized from medial to lateral as follows:

 

2. General visceral: The general visceral column carries sensory information from the internal organs, such as the visceral sensations of hunger, fullness, and discomfort.

 

4. Special visceral: This column includes sensory input related to the special senses of taste and hearing. The special visceral sensory column carries information from the taste buds and the cochlea (auditory part of the ear).

 

1. General somatic: The general somatic column carries sensory information related to touch, temperature, pain, and pressure from the body's skin and musculoskeletal system.

 

3. Special somatic: This column contains sensory input related to the special senses of vision, equilibrium, and proprioception (awareness of body position). It includes input from the eyes, ears (for balance), and proprioceptors in muscles and joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the floor of the fourth ventricle, the arrangement of the afferent sensory columns from medial to lateral is - 2. General visceral, 4. Special visceral, 1. General somatic & 3. Special somatic

questions.text: What TNM stage is appropriate for a woman with a breast lump and peau d'orange appearance affecting more than two-thirds of the breast?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T4d

 

Peau d'orange (orange peel appearance) is a clinical sign indicating skin involvement in breast cancer. The TNM staging system for breast cancer classifies tumors with peau d'orange under T4b. However, when the peau d'orange affects a significant portion of the breast, specifically more than one-third of the breast skin, it indicates a more advanced stage known as inflammatory breast carcinoma, which is classified as T4d.

 

Given the information that the peau d'orange affects more than two-thirds of the breast, the appropriate TNM stage is T4d, signifying inflammatory breast carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4a: This is incorrect as T4a refers to the extension of the tumor to the chest wall.

 

Option B. T4b: This is incorrect as T4b includes peau d'orange but only when it involves less than one-third of the breast skin.

 

Option C. T4c: This is incorrect as T4c is a combination of T4a and T4b, indicating extension to the chest wall and skin involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange affecting more than one-third of the breast skin is classified as T4d, indicating inflammatory breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3 years

 

At age of 3 years, handedness is seen. The child may become frustrated if attempts are made in changing the hand preference.

 

Other milestones reached at 3 years-

 

  • Rides tricycle
  • Alternate feet going upstairs
  • Builds a tower of 9 blocks
  • Copies a circle
  • Knows full name and gender

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 year: Standing without support comes by 1 year

 

Option B. 2 years: A child has vocab of 100 words by 2 years

 

Option D. 4 years: A child can tell poem & stories by 4 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

questions.text: In a study involving a population, where the mean value is 200, if the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 180-220

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD →Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD →Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD →Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

So, 68% population will cover, Mean ± 1SD.

Mean = 200

Standard Deviation = 20

 

68% population will lie between = 200 ± 20 = 180 - 220

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Luteal phase LH
Post luteal phase LH
FSH in the follicular phase

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • Values and Interpretation:
    • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
    • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
    • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL

 

Tests for ovarian reserve:

 

  • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg435

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

 

The condition shown in the image is characterized by painful vesicles, which is a hallmark of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. HSV causes fluid-filled vesicles that are often painful, and these lesions can occur on the skin or mucous membranes, including genital areas. The vesicles eventually rupture, forming shallow, painful ulcers. HSV can present as recurrent outbreaks, especially during periods of stress or weakened immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Candidiasis typically presents with white, curd-like discharge and redness, particularly in mucous membranes like the mouth or vagina. It does not cause vesicles or painful ulcers.

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless chancre in the primary stage, followed by a rash and other systemic symptoms in later stages. Vesicles are not a feature of syphilis.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with painful genital ulcers but does not form fluid-filled vesicles. The ulcers are more ragged and deeper compared to those seen in HSV infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.

 

To perform Kirby-Bauer's disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

 

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

 

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E-test (Epsilometer)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: This method involves incorporating different concentrations of antibiotics into agar plates. It's primarily a quantitative technique that provides the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of antibiotics.

 

Option C. Broth dilution method: Similar to the agar dilution method but performed in a liquid medium. This method also determines the MIC of antibiotics.

 

Option D. PCR based assay: This molecular method detects the presence of specific antibiotic resistance genes but does not directly test the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

The given clinical scenario, image showing a patient with polypoidal mass and HPE image revealing sporangium, points to a diagnosis of Rhinosporidiosis.

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)

  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.

  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas

  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.

  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness

  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)

  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

Other Options:

Option A. Nasal polyp: Typically presents as a non-neoplastic mass, usually bilateral and associated with conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis. They do not bleed on touch and do not have the characteristic histopathological findings seen in Rhinosporidiosis.

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumors that appear as reddish-blue lesions, which are compressible and usually do not present with the same histopathological features as Rhinosporidiosis.

Option D. Rhinophyma: A severe form of rosacea resulting in a large, bulbous, and red nose. It is not associated with nasal bleeding or the histopathological findings presented in this case.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen Sclerosus

 

The given image shows Lichen Sclerosus.

 

  • Lichen Sclerosus usually presents in postmenopausal women. Lichen sclerosus is one of the common dermatoses to affect the ano‐genital skin
  • The presenting symptom is usually itching, which is often severe and distressing. Patients may also complain of discomfort and dyspareunia if there is introital narrowing Perianal involvement frequently manifests as a figure-8 shape.
  • White, atrophic papules with abnormal anatomy distortion are the typical appearance. These papules may coalesce into plaques.
  • It is possible for introital stenosis, clitoral concealment, labia minora regression, and urethral obstruction to occur. A biopsy is required to rule out cancer.
  • Topical corticosteroids remain the first line of treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget Disease: Usually manifests as red, scaly, and crusty patches on the vulvar skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not present with white atrophic papules as shown in the question.

 

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

Presents with purplish, flat-topped, itchy papules and plaques, often with a reticular pattern on mucous membranes, not typically white atrophic papules.

 

Option D. Angioma of Vulva:

 

This would present as a benign growth of small blood vessels and would be red and vascular in appearance as shown below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When encountering white atrophic papules and plaques on the vulva that may coalesce and distort the vulvar anatomy, lichen sclerosus should be considered as a primary diagnosis.

 

Premalignant lesions of vulva:

 

  • Vulvar Intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  • Paget’s disease
  • Lichen sclerosus
  • Condyloma acuminata
  • Bowen disease (Erythroplasia of Queyrat)

 

Ref - William’s gynecology 4th edition Page no 92-100, 688

Shaw’s textbook of gynecology, 17th edition Page no 323, 473-475

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6298145/

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

 

  • Hepatic glycogenolysis involves the breakdown of glycogen stored in the liver into glucose. This process provides source of blood glucose for 12-18 hours, So By 7 am the next day, liver's glycogen stores is the main source of blood glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dietary Glucose: Dietary glucose from the previous evening's meal would have been absorbed and utilized or stored shortly after eating. By 7 am the next day, the influence of dietary glucose on blood glucose levels would have diminished significantly. It is unlikely to be the primary source of the elevated glucose.

 

Option B. Hepatic Gluconeogenesis: Hepatic gluconeogenesis is the process by which the liver produces glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors, such as amino acids and glycerol. During overnight fasting, the liver actively engages in gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels. It happens mainly only after 18 hours or more of fasting.

 

Option D. Muscle Glycogenolysis: Muscle glycogenolysis primarily supplies glucose for use within muscle tissue itself and is not a major contributor to blood glucose levels during fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded).  After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).

 

Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).

 

Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 176

questions.text: A patient with Reinke’s edema will have which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dysphonia

 

  • Dysphonia is the hallmark symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • The swelling in the vocal cords alters their vibration, leading to changes in voice quality, pitch, and loudness.
  • Patients often present with a deep, husky voice, and in severe cases, speech may become effortful.

 

Reinke’s Edema is polypoid degeneration of vocal cords. It is bilateral symmetrical swelling of the whole of membranous part of the vocal cords. This is due to oedema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords.

 

 

 

Etiology – Chronic irritation of vocal cords due to misuse of voice, heavy smoking, chronic sinusitis and laryngopharyngeal reflex.

 

Clinical features – Hoarseness, Dysphonia, patient uses false cords for voice production and this gives him a low-pitched and rough voice.

 

On indirect laryngoscopy, vocal cords appear as fusiform swellings with pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

 

Treatment - Decortication of the vocal cords, Voice rest and Speech therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dysphagia to Solids and Option C. Dysphagia to Liquids:

 

These symptoms relate to difficulty swallowing, which is not typically associated with Reinke’s edema unless there is significant involvement of adjacent structures affecting the swallowing mechanism, which is rare.

 

Option D. Diplophonia:

 

  • Diplophonia (the perception of two simultaneous pitches) can occur in conditions affecting vocal cord vibration but is not a classic feature of Reinke’s edema.
  • It may be observed in some cases of vocal cord lesions, such as polyps or cysts, but it is not a primary symptom of Reinke’s edema.
  • Usually diplophonia is seen in unilateral vocal cord pathologies. The affected cord vibrates at a different frequency when compared with the normal cord which vibrates at its regular frequency. This is because vibrational characteristics of affected cord gets changed due to structural changes caused by the lesion. Hence 2 cords, vibrating at 2 different frequencies, will produce 2 different sounds. This is called as diplophonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke's edema primarily affects the vocal cords leading to characteristic symptoms related to voice changes where the patient may experience pain due to movement of swollen vocal cords. Heavy vocal cords require more effort by the vocal muscles to move them. Hence this extra effort of muscles causes pain and early vocal fatigue to the patient. Management involves addressing the underlying causes, surgical intervention, and supportive therapies like voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Restriction of water intake and wait and watch

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alpha blocker

 

Alpha blocker will be used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

 

Alpha blockers

 

  • Most commonly preferred ones are α1A blockers like Tamsulosin and Silodosin.

  • They do not lead to postural hypotension, which can be seen with selective α1 blockers like Prazosin, Doxazosin etc.

  • Later block α1 receptors in the blood vessels as well, leading to vasodilation.

  • However, these drugs have no effect on the size of the prostate gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restriction of water intake and wait and watch: While lifestyle modifications, including reducing fluid intake, may help manage symptoms to some extent, they are not sufficient for the initial management of significant irritative symptoms caused by BPH.

 

Option C. Prostatectomy: This is a surgical procedure to remove the prostate gland. It is typically reserved for severe cases of BPH or when other treatments have failed. It is not the initial management step.

 

Option D. Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP): TURP is a surgical procedure to remove parts of the prostate that are causing obstruction. It is effective but generally considered after medical management, such as alpha blockers, has been tried.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha blockers, particularly α1A blockers like tamsulosin and silodosin, are used for the initial management of irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia. These medications help alleviate symptoms by relaxing the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, improving urine flow without significantly affecting blood pressure.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause side effects such as headache, flushing, and peripheral edema, but it is not typically associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. Its common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities, but it does not cause angioedema.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It can cause side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and rebound hypertension upon abrupt withdrawal, but it is not associated with angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-

 

  • Angioedema
  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: Match the condition with the appropriate diagnostic test: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 1, B 2, C 3, D 4

 

  1. Hirschsprung's disease is diagnosed by rectal biopsy, which is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition.
  2. Posterior urethral valve is diagnosed by micturating cystourethrogram, which is a radiographic imaging test of the bladder and urethra during voiding.
  3. Choledochal cyst is diagnosed by MRCP, which is a non-invasive imaging test that uses magnetic resonance imaging to visualize the biliary tree.
  4. Intussusception is diagnosed by CT scan, which is a diagnostic imaging test that provides detailed images of the abdominal organs and structures.

 

Explanation:

 

A. Hirschsprung's disease: This is a congenital disorder in which nerve cells (ganglion cells) are absent from a segment of the bowel, usually the rectum or sigmoid colon, leading to a functional obstruction. Infants with Hirschsprung's typically have difficulty with bowel movements within the first days of life. The symptoms can include constipation, abdominal distension, and vomiting. It is diagnosed often in the neonatal period with a barium enema and confirmed with suction rectal biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells.

 

B. Posterior urethral valve (PUV): PUV is a congenital malformation in male child where an abnormality of the posterior urethra prevents urine outflow. This can lead to urinary obstruction, distension of the bladder, and can subsequently cause damage to the kidneys. Common symptoms include weak urine stream, difficulty in urination, recurrent urinary tract infections, and failure to thrive. Diagnosis is usually made with a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

 

C. Choledochal cyst: This is a congenital dilation of the bile ducts, often causing obstruction. Patients may present with the classic triad of abdominal pain, jaundice, and an abdominal mass, although not all these signs may be evident. Over time, choledochal cysts can lead to complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, or even malignancy. Diagnosis is typically done with imaging like ultrasound or MRCP, and definitive treatment is surgical removal.

 

D. Intussusception: This is a medical condition in which a part of the intestine telescopes into another section, leading to bowel obstruction. It is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in children between the ages of 6 months and 3 years. Symptoms include sudden, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and "currant jelly" stools (due to mucus and blood). The diagnosis can often be made with an ultrasound or CT abdomen showing the characteristic "target sign" and is typically treated with high pressure enema, although some cases may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Component bar graph

 

  • The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.
  • A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.
  • In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Histogram is used for continuous quantitative data presentation.

 

 

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are

 

separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

 

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

 

Option B. Line Diagram: Is a better chart Used in depiction of TREND. There is no closed loop and no histogram in the background.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Bar Graphs: Multiple bar graphs show two or more sets of data simultaneously with separate bars for each category side by side. This is different from a component bar graph, where each bar is divided into segments representing different components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior mesenteric vein

 

The structure shown by the arrow is SMV.

 

SMV is on the right, while SMA is on the left (Remember "SMAL").

 

They can be identified by the uncinate process at this level

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Superior Mesenteric Vein can be distinguished on a CT scan by its position to the right of the Superior Mesenteric Artery, and its relation to the uncinate process. Remembering "SMAL" (Superior Mesenteric Artery Left, Superior Mesenteric Vein Right) can aid in identification during diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A diabetic elderly man presents with dyspnea and pedal edema. A chest X-ray (CXR) shows an enlarged heart with rales. Echo reveals a low ejection fraction (EF). Which of the following treatments will delay the progression of cardiac disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a medication that belongs to the class of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. Although it is primarily used to manage diabetes by promoting glucose excretion through urine, it has been found to have significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Mechanism of Action in Heart Failure: Empagliflozin improves cardiac outcomes through several mechanisms:

 

  • Reduction in preload and afterload: By promoting diuresis and natriuresis, empagliflozin reduces the volume overload, which is beneficial in heart failure.
  • Improvement in myocardial metabolism: It shifts myocardial substrate utilization from glucose to ketone bodies, which is more energy-efficient for the failing heart.
  • Reduction in cardiac fibrosis and inflammation: Empagliflozin has anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects, which help in reducing cardiac remodeling and progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrochlorothiazide: This is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to manage hypertension and mild fluid retention. However, it does not have significant benefits in delaying the progression of heart failure.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not specifically alter the progression of the disease.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin is used in heart failure to improve symptoms and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, but it does not have a mortality benefit or significantly delay the progression of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, although primarily an anti-diabetic medication, has been shown to significantly benefit patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) by delaying the progression of the disease through its effects on diuresis, myocardial metabolism, and cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: Monkeypox detection is best done by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Real-Time PCR

 

Monkeypox virus is a double-stranded DNA virus, and the most effective method for detecting DNA viruses is through Real-Time PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction). Real-Time PCR allows for the rapid and precise amplification of DNA, making it a highly sensitive and specific tool for detecting the presence of the Monkeypox virus in a sample. This method can detect even small amounts of viral DNA, making it the best option for early and accurate diagnosis.

 

In cases where the pathogen is an RNA virus, the detection process typically starts with Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), where RNA is first converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) before amplification. However, since Monkeypox is a DNA virus, Real-Time PCR is directly applicable without the need for this additional step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA: While ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) is useful for detecting antibodies or antigens related to an infection, it is not the most direct or sensitive method for detecting the DNA of the Monkeypox virus.

 

Option B. Hemagglutination: Hemagglutination is a method used to detect viruses that cause red blood cells to clump together. This method is not applicable for detecting Monkeypox virus, which does not cause hemagglutination.

 

Option C. Western Blot: Western Blot is used primarily to detect specific proteins in a sample and is more commonly associated with confirming the presence of antibodies, such as in HIV testing. It is not the best method for detecting a DNA virus like Monkeypox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Real-Time PCR is the most effective and reliable method for detecting Monkeypox virus, a double-stranded DNA virus, due to its sensitivity and specificity
